titleStmt.title: Anonymous (Elizabethan) : : A warning for fair women (1599)

publicationStmt.publisher: Anonymous (Elizabethan) (fl.1599) A Warning for Faire Women. Containing, The most tragicall and lamentable murther of Master George Sanders of London Marchant, nigh Shooters hill. Consented vnto By his owne wife, acted by M. Browne, Mistris Drewry and Trusty Roger agents therin: with their seuerall ends. As it hath beene lately diuerse times acted by the right Honorable, the Lord Chamberlaine his Seruantes London Printed ... by Valentine Sims for William Aspley 1599

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
A warning for fair women. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1599. Date first performed: 1596-1600.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

stage.l: Enter at one door, History with Drum and Ensign:
Tragedy at another, in her one hand a whip, in

sp.l: Wither away so fast? peace with that drum:
Down with that ensign which disturbs our stage
Out with this luggage, with this foppery,
This brawling sheepskin is intolerable.
Indeed no marvel though we should give place
Unto a common executioner:
Room, room, for Gods sake, let us stand away,
O we shall have some doughty stuff to say.

stage.l: Enter Comedy at the other end.

sp.l: What yet more Cats guts? O this filthy sound
Stifles mine ears:
More cartwheels cracking yet?
A plague upon it, I will cut your fiddle strings,
If you stand scraping thus to anger me.
Gup mistress buskins with a whirligig, are you so touchy
Madam Melpomine, whose mare is dead
That you are going to take off her skin?
A plague upon these filthy fiddling tricks,
Able to poison any noble wit:
Avoid the stage or I will whip you hence.
Indeed thou mayst, for thou art Murthers Beadle,
The common hangman unto Tyranny.
But History, what all three met at once?
What wonder is towards that we are got together?
My meaning was to have been here today,
But meeting with my Lady Tragedy,
She scolds me off:
And Comedy, except thou canst prevail,
I think she means to banish us the stage.
Tut, tut, she cannot: she may for a day
Or two perhaps be had in some request,
But once a week if we do not appear,
She shall find few that will attend her here.
I must confess you have some sparks of wit,
Some odd ends of old jests scraped up together,
To tickle shallow injudicial ears,
Perhaps some puling passion of a lover, but slight and
childish,
What is this to me?
I must have passions that must move the soul,
Make the heart heavy, and throb within the bosom,
Extorting tears out of the strictest eyes,
To rack a thought and strain it to his form,
Until I rap the senses from their course,
This is my office.
How some damned tyrant to obtain a crown,
Stabs, hangs, impoisons, smothers, cutteth throats,
And then a Chorus too comes howling in,
And tells us of the worrying of a cat,
Then of a filthy whining ghost,
Lapped in some foul sheet, or a leather pelt,
Comes screaming like a pig half sticked,
And cries Vindicta, revenge, revenge:
With that a little Rosen flasheth forth,
Like smoke out of a Tobacco pipe, or a boys squib:
Then comes in two or three like to drovers,
With tailors bodkins, stabbing one another,
Is not this trim? is not here goodly things?
That you should be so much accounted of,
I would not else.
Now before God thou wilt make her mad anon,
Thy jests are like a Wisp unto a scold.
Why say I could: What care I History?
Then shall we have a tragedy indeed:
Pure purple Buskin, blood and murther right.
Thus with your loose and idle similes,
You have abused me: but I will whip you hence,
I will scourge and lash you both from off the stage,
It is you have kept the Theatres so long,
Painted in playbills, upon every post,
That I am scorned of the multitude,
My name profaned: but now I will reign as Queen
In great Apollos name and all the Muses,
By virtue of whose Godhead I am sent,
I charge you to be gone and leave this place.
Look Comedy, I marked it not till now,
The stage is hung with black: and I perceive
The Auditors prepared for Tragedy.
Nay then I see she shall be entertained,
These ornaments beseem not thee and me,
Then Tragedy, kill them today with sorrow,
We will make them laugh with mirthful jests tomorrow.
And Tragedy although today thou reign,
Tomorrow here I will domineer again.
Are you both gone so soon? why then I see
All this fair circuit here is left to me:
All you spectators, turn your cheerful eye,
Give entertainment unto Tragedy,
My Scene is London, native and your own,
I sigh to think, my subject too well known,
I am not feigned: many now in this round,
Once to behold me in sad tears were drowned,
Yet what I am, I will not let you know,
Until my next ensuing scene shall show.

stage.l: Enter Sanders, Anne Sand: Drurie, Browne, Roger and master

sp.l: Gentleman, here must we take our leave,
Thanking you for your courteous company,
And for your good discourse of Ireland,
Whereas it seems you have been resident,
By your well noting the particulars.
True sir, I have been there familiar,
And am no better known in London here,
Than I am there unto the better sort,
Chiefly in Dublin where ye heard me say,
Are as great feasts as this we had today.
So have I heard, the land gives good increase,
Of every blessing for the use of man,
And it is great pity the inhabitants,
Will not be civil, nor live under law.
As civil in the English pale as here,
And laws obeyed, and orders duly kept,
And all the rest may one day be reduced.
God grand it so: I pray you what is your name?
My name is George Browne.
God be with ye good master Browne.
Many farewells master Sanders to yourself,
And to these Gentlewomen: Ladies, God be with you.
God be with ye sir.
Thanks for your company,
I like your talk of Ireland so well
That I could wish time had not cut it off,
I pray ye sir if ye come near my house
Call, and you shall be welcome master Browne.
I thank ye mistress Drurie: is it not so?
My name is Anne Drurie.
Widow, come, will ye go?
I will wait upon you sir.

stage.l: Exeunt Sanders. A. San. makes a courtesy and departs,
and all the rest saving Roger, whom Browne calls.

sp.l: Hark ye, my friend,
Are not you servant unto mistress Drurie?
Yes indeed forsooth, for fault of a better,
I have served her (man and boy) this seven years.
I pray thee do me a piece of favour then,
And I will requite it.
Anything I can.
Entreat thy mistress when she takes her leave,
Of master Sanders and his wife, to make retire
Hither again, for I will speak with her.
Wilt thou do it for me?
Yea sir that I will.
Where shall she find ye?
I will not stir from hence:
Say I entreat her but a word or two,
She shall not stay longer than likes herself.
Nay sir for that as you two can agree,
I will warrant you I will bring her to ye straight.
Straight or crooked, I must needs speak with her,
For by this light my heart is not my own,
But taken prisoner at this frolic feast,
Entangled in a net of golden wire,
Which love had slyly laid in her fair looks.
O master Sanders thou art a happy man,
To have so sweet a creature to thy wife,
Whom I must win, or I must lose my life,
But if she be as modest as she seems,
Thy heart may break George Browne ere thou obtain.
This mistress Drurie must be made the mean,
Whatever it cost to compass my
desire,
And I hope well, she doth so soon retire,
Good mistress Drurie pardon this bold part
That I have played upon so small acquaintance,
To send for you, let your good nature hide
The blame of my bad nurture for this once.
I take it for a favour master Browne,
And no offence, a man of your fair parts,
Will send for me to steed him any way.
Sir, ye shall find my mistress as courteous a gentle-woman,
as any is in London, if ye have occasion to use
her.
So I presume friend, mistress by your leave,
I would not that your man should hear our speech,
For it concerns me much it be concealed.
I hope it is no treason you will speak.
No by my faith, nor felony.
Nay then, though my man Roger hear it, never care
If it be love, or secrets due to that,
Roger is trusty I dare pawn my life,
As any fellow within London walls,
But if you have some secret malady,
That craves my help, to use my surgery,
Which though I say it is pretty: he shall hence,
If not, be bold to speak, there is no offence.
I have no sore, but a new inward grief,
Which by your physic may find some relief.
What, is it a surfeit?
Aye, at this late feast.
Why, Aqua cœletis, or the water of balm,
Or Rosa solis, or that of Doctor Steeuens
Will help a surfeit. Now I remember me,
Mistress Sanders hath a sovereign thing,
To help a sudden surfeit presently.
I think she have: how shall I compass it?
I will send my man for some of it.
Pray ye stay.
She will never send that which will do me good.
O say not so, for then ye know her not.
I would I did so well as I could wish
She is even as courteous a gentlewoman Sir,
As kind a peat, as London can afford:
Not send it quoth he? yes and bring it herself,
If need require: a poor woman the other day,
Her water-bearers wife, had surfeited
With eating beans (ye know it is windy meat)
And the poor creature is subject to the stone:
She went herself, and gave her but a dram,
It holp her strait, in less than half an hour
She fell unto her business till she sweat,
And was as well as I am now.
But that which helps a woman helps not me.
A woman's help will rather do me good.
I'faith I have found you, are ye such one?
Well Master Browne, I warrant, let you alone.
But Mistress Drewry, leave me not yet alone,
For if ye do, I never shall alone
Obtain the company that my soul desires:
Faith tell me one thing, can ye not do much
With Mistress Sanders, are you not inward with her?
I dare presume to do as much with her,
As any woman in this city can.
What is your opinion of her honesty?
O very honest, very chaste i'faith,
I will not wrong her for a thousand pound.
Then all your physic cannot cure my wound
Your wound is love, is that your surfeit sir?
Yea, and it is cureless without help of her.
I am very sorry that I cannot ease ye,
Well, if ye can, i'faith I will well please ye.
You wear a pretty turkess there methinks,
I would I had the fellow of it.
Take ye this,
Upon condition to effect my bliss.
Pardon me that sir, no condition,
For that grief I am no physician,
How sayst thou Roger, am I?
Yea forsooth mistress, what? what did ye ask?
This gentleman is in love
With mistress Sanders, and would have me speak
On his behalf, how sayst thou, dare I do it,
And she so honest, wise and virtuous?
What mean ye mistress Drurie to bewray,
Unto your man, what I in secret spake?
Tush, fear not you, it is trusty Roger this,
I use his counsel in as deep affairs,
How sayst thou Hodge?
Mistress, this say I: though mistress Sanders be very
honest, as in my conscience she is, and her husband wise
and
subtle, and in all Belinsgate-ward not a kinder couple, yet
if
you would wrong her husband your dear friend, methinks ye
have such a sweet tongue, as will supple a stone, and
for my
life, if ye list to labour, you will win her. Sir
sticke close to my
mistress, she is studying the law: and if ye be not straight
laced
ye know my mind, she will do it for ye, and I will
play my part.
Here Mi. Drurie this same ring is yours,
Wear it for my sake, and if ye do me good,
Command this chain, this hand, and this heart blood,
What say ye to me? speak a cheerful word.
Faith mistress do, he is a fine gentleman,
Pity he should languish for a little love.
Yea but thou knowest they are both my friends,
He is very wise, she very circumspect,
Very respective of her honest
name.
If ye list you can cover as great a blame.
If I should break it, and she take it ill.
Tut, you have cunning, pray ye use your skill;
To her master Browne.
What say ye to me Lady?
This I say.
I cannot make a man, to cast away
So goodly a creature as yourself, were sin:
Second my onset, for I will begin
To break the ice that you may pass the ford,
Do your good will, you shall have my good word.
But how shall I have opportunity?
That must be watched, but very
secretly.
How? at her house?
There ye may not enter.
How then?
By some other fine adventure,
Watch when her husband goes to the Exchange,
She will sit at door: to her though she be strange,
Spare not to speak, ye can but be denied,
Women love most, by whom they are most tried,
My man shall watch, and I will watch my turn,
I cannot see so fair a Gallant mourn.
Ye bless my soul by showing me the way,
O mistress Drurie, if I do obtain,
Do but imagine how I will quit your pain,
But where is her house?
Against S. Dunstones church.
S. Dunstones in Fleet street?
No, near Belinsgate,
Dunstone is in the East, that is in the West,
Be bold to speak for I will do my best.
Thanks mistress Drurie, Roger drink you that,
And as I speed expect your recompense.
I thank ye sir, nay I will gage my hand,
Few women can my mistress force withstand.
Sir, this is all ye have to say?
For this time mistress Drurie we will part.
Win mistress Sanders, and ye win my heart.
Hope you the best, she shall have much ado,
To hold her own when I begin to move: come Hodge.
I trust sir when my mistress has obtained your suit,
You will suit me in a cast suit of your apparel.
Cast and uncast shall trusty Roger have,
If thou be secret, and an honest knave.

stage.l: Enter Anne Sanders with her little son, and sit

sp.l: Pray ye mother when shall we go to supper?
Why, when your father comes from the Exchange,
Ye are not hungry since ye came from school.
Not hungry (mother,) but I would fain eat.
Forbear a while until your father come,
I sit here to expect his quick return.
Mother, shall not I have new bow and shafts,
Against our school go afeasting?
Yes if ye learn,
And against Easter new apparel too.
You will lend me all your scarfs, and all your rings,
And buy me a white feather for my velvet cap,
Will ye mother? yea say, pray ye say so.
Go prattling boy, go bid your sister see
My Closet locked when she takes out the fruit.
I will forsooth, and take some for my pains.
Well sir sauce, does your master teach ye that?
I pray God bless thee, thou art a very
wag.
Yonder she sits to light this obscure street,
Like a bright diamond worn in some dark place,
Or like the moon in a black winters night,
To comfort wandering travellers in their way,
But so demure, so modest are her looks,
So chaste her eyes, so virtuous her aspect,
As do repulse loves false Artillery;
Yet must I speak though checked with scornful nay,
Desire draws on, but Reason bids me stay,
My Tutoress Drurie gave me charge to speak:
And speak I must, or else my heart will break.
God save ye mistress Sanders, all alone?
Sit ye to take the view of passengers?
No in good sooth sir, I give small regard
Who comes, or goes, my husband I attend,
Whose coming will be speedy from the Exchange,
A good exchange made he for single life,
That joined in marriage with so sweet a wife.
Come ye to speak with master Sanders sir?
Why ask ye that?
Because ye make a stay,
Here at his door.
I stay in courtesy,
To give you thanks for your last company,
I hope my kind salute doth not offend?
No sir, and yet such unexpected kindness,
is like herb Iohn in broth.
I pray ye how is that?
It may even as well be laid aside as used,
If ye have business with my husband sir,
Ye are welcome, otherwise I will take my leave.
Nay gentle mistress, let not my access
Be means to drive you from your door so soon:
I would be loath to prejudice your pleasure,
For my good liking at the feast conceived,
If master Sanders shall have cause to use,
The favour of some noble personage,
Let him employ no other but George Browne,
To effect his suit without a recompense,
I speak I know not what, my tongue and heart,
Are so divided through the force of Love.
I thank ye sir, but if he have such cause,
I hope he is not so void of friends in Court,
But he may speed and never trouble you,
Yet I will do your errand if ye please.
Even as it please you: I doubt I trouble ye.
Resolve your doubt, and trouble me no more.
It will never be: I thought as much before.
God be with you Mistress.
Fare ye well, good sir.
I will to Nan Drewry yet, and talk with her.
These arrant-making Gallants are good men,
That cannot pass and see a woman sit
Of any sort, alone at any door,
But they will find a scuse to stand and prate,
Fools that they are to bite at every bait.
Here he comes now whom I have looked for long.
How now sweet Nan, sittest thou here all alone?
Better alone, than have bad company.
I trust there is none but good resorts to thee.
There shall not sir, if I know what they be:
Ye have stayed late sir at the Exchange tonight.
Upon occasion Nan, is supper ready?
An hour ago.
And what good company?
None to sup with us? Send one for Nan Drewry,
She will play the wag, tell tales, and make us
merry.
I think she has supped, but one shall run and look;
If your meat be marred, blame yourself, not the cook.
However it be, we will take
it in good part
For once and use it not, come, let us in
sweetheart.

stage.l: Enter Anne Drewry, and Trusty Roger her man,

sp.l: Roger come hither, was there no messenger
This day from master Browne to speak with me?
Mistress, not any, and that I marvel at:
But I can tell you, he must come and send,
And be no niggard of his purse beside,
Or else I know how it will go with him:
Ye must not think to anchor where he hopes,
Unless you be his pilot.
Where is that?
The fellow talks and prates he knows not what,
I be his pilot? whither? canst thou tell?
The cause he doth frequent my house thou seest,
Is for the love he bears unto my daughter.
A very good cloak mistress for the
rain,
And therein I must needs commend your wit,
Close dealing is the safest; by that means
The world will be the less suspicious:
For whilst it is thought he doth
affect your daughter,
Who can suspect his love to mistress Sanders?
Why now thou art as I would have thee be
Conceited, and of quick capacity,
Some heavy draw-latch would have been this month,
(Though hourly I had instructed him)
Before he could have found my policy.
But Hodge, thou art my hearts interpreter,
And be thou secret still, as thou hast been,
And doubt not but we will all gain by the match:
George Browne as thou knowest is well reckoned of.
A proper man and hath good store of coin,
And mistress Sanders she is young and fair,
And may be tempered easily like wax.
Especially by one that is familiar with her.
True mistress, nor is she the first by many,
That you have won to stoop unto the lure,
It is your trade, your living, what needs more?
Drive you the bargain, I will keep the door.
Trusty Roger, thou well deservest thy name,
But mistress, shall I tell you what I think?
Yes Hodge, what is it?
If you will be ruled by me,
Let them pay well for what you undertake:
Be not a spokeswoman mistress for none of them,
But be the better for it: times will change,
And there is no trusting to uncertainties.
Dost think I will? then beg me for a fool,
The money I will finger twixt them twain
Shall make my daughter such a dowry,
As I will match her better than with Browne,
To some rich Attorney, or Gentleman:
Let me alone, if they enjoy their pleasure,
My sweet shall be to feed upon their treasure.
Hold you there mistress: here comes mast. Browne.
Good morrow mistress Drurie.
What master Browne,
Now by my faith you are the very last man
We talked of: ye are welcome sir, how do you?
And how speed you concerning that you wot of?
Mistress, I will void the place, if so you please.
And give you leave in private to confer.
Whither goes Roger? call him back again.
Come hither sirrah, M. Browne will have you stay.
Why how now Roger? will you shrink from me?
Because I saw you not, do you suppose
I make no reckoning of your company.
What man? thy trust is it I build upon.
I thank you sir: nay pray you be not offended,
I would be loath to seem unmannerly.
Tut a figs end: thy council will do well,
And we must use thee, therefore tarry here,
I have no other secret to reveal,
But only this, that I have broke
the ice,
And made an entrance to my loves pursuit:
Sweet mistress Sanders that choice argument
Of all perfection, sitting at her door
Even now I did salute: some words there past,
But nothing to the purpose, neither time,
Nor place consorted to my mind: beside,
Recourse of servants, and of passengers
Might have been jealous of our conference:
And therefore I refrained all large discourse,
Only thus much I gathered by her speech,
That she is affable, not coy, nor scornful,
And may be won, would you but be entreated
To be a mediator for me, and persuade her.
I pray you do so mistress, you do know
That master Brown is an honest gentleman,
And I dare swear will recompense you well.
If she do mistrust me, there is my purse,
And in the same ten angels of good gold,
And when I can but have access to her,
And am in any possibility
To win her favour, challenge of me more,
A hundred pound in marriage with your daughter.
Alas how dare I master Browne her husband
Is one that I am much beholding to,
A man both loving, bountiful and just,
And to his wife, in all this city, none
More kind, more loyal hearts, or more firm,
What sin were it to do him then that wrong?
O speak not of his worth, but of her praise,
If he be firm, she is fair, if he bountiful,
She is beautiful, if he loyal, she is lovely,
If he, in all the City for a man
Be the most absolute, she, in all the world
Is for a woman the most excellent:
O earth hath seldom such a creature seen:
Nor subject been possessed with such a love.
Mistress, can you hear this, and not be moved
I would it lay in me to help you sir,
I'faith you should not need so many words.
I know that, thou hast always
been my friend,
And though I never see Anne Sanders more,
Yet for my sake drink this: and mistress Drewrie,
England I must be forced to bid farewell,
Or shortly look to hear that I am dead,
Unless I may prevail to get her love.
Good mistress leave your dumps, and speak to him.
You need not study so, it is no such labour:
Alas, will you see a gentleman cast away?
All is but George, I pray you let be done.
Well master Browne, not for your monies sake
So much, as in regard I love you well,
Am I content to be your Orator,
Mistress Sanders shall be certified,
How fervently you love her, and withal,
Some other words I will use on your behalf,
As you shall have access to her at least.
I ask no more, when will you undertake it?
This day, it shall no longer be deferred.
And in the evening you shall know an answer.
Here at your house?
Yea here if so you please.
No better place, I rest upon your promise:
So farewell mistress Drurie till that hour,
What sweet can earth afford will not seem sour.
He is sped i'faith: come Roger let us go,
Ill is the wind doth no man profit blow.
I shall not be the worse for it, that I know.

stage.l: Enter master Sanders and his man.

sp.l: Sirrah, what bills of debt are due to me?
All that were due sir as this day, are paid.
You have enough then to discharge
the bond
Of master Ashmores fifteen hundred pound,
That must be tendered on the Exchange tonight.
With that which master Bishop owes, we have.
When is his time to pay?
This afternoon.
He is a sure man, thou needst not doubt of him.
In any case take heed unto my credit,
I do not use (thou knowest) to break my word,
Much less my bond; I prithee look unto it,
And when as master Bishop sends his money,
Bring the whole sum: I will be upon the Burse,
Or if I be not, thou canst take a quittance.
What shall I say unto my mistress, sir?
She bade me tell out thirty pounds even now,
She meant to have bestowed in linen cloth.
She must defer her market till tomorrow,
I know no other shift: my great affairs
Must not be hindered by such trifling wares.
She told me sir the Draper would be here,
And George the Milliner with other things,
Which she appointed should be brought her home.
All is one for that, another time shall serve,
Nor is there any such necessity,
But she may very well forbear a
while.
She will not so be answered at my hand.
Tell her I did command it should be so.
Your pleasure shall be done sir, though thereby
It is I am like to bear the blame away.

stage.l: Enter Anne Sanders, mistress Drurie, a Draper

sp.l: Come near I pray you, I do like your linen,
and you shall have your price: but you my friend, the gloves
you showed me, and the Italian purse are both well made.
and I do like the fashion, but trust me, the perfume I am
afraid will not continue, yet upon your word I will
have
them too. Sirrah where is your Master?
Forsooth he is gone to the Exchange even now.
Have you the money ready which I called for?
No, if it please you, my master gave me charge I
should deliver none.
How is that sir knave?
Your master charged you should deliver none?
Go to, dispatch and fetch me thirty pound,
Or I will send my fingers to your lips.
Good fortune, thus incensed against her husband,
I shall the better break with her for Browne.
I pray you mistress pacify yourself,
I dare not do it.
You dare not, and why so?
Because there is money to be paid tonight,
Upon an obligation.
What of that?
Therefore I may not have to serve my turn,
Indeed forsooth there is not in the house,
As yet sufficient to discharge that debt.
It is well that I must stand at your reversion,
Entreat my prentice, courtesy to my man:
And he must be purse-bearer, when I need,
This was not wont to be your masters order.
No, I will be sworn of that: I never knew,
But that you had at all times mistress Sanders,
A greater sum than that at a command,
Marry perhaps the world may now be changed.
Feed not my mistress anger, mistress Drewery,
You do not well: tomorrow if she list,
It is not twice so much but she may have it.
So that my breach of credit, in the while
Is not regarded: I have brought these men,
To have their money for such necessaries,
As I have bought, and they have honestly
Delivered to my hands, and now forsooth,
I must be thought so bare and beggarly,
As they must be put off until tomorrow.
Good mistress Sanders trouble not yourself,
If that be all, your word shall be sufficient,
Were it for thrice the value of my ware.
And trust me mistress you shall do me wrong,
If otherwise you do conceit of me,
Be it for a week, a fortnight, or a month,
Or when you will, I never would desire
Better security for all I am worth.
I thank you for your gentleness my friends,
But I have never used to go on credit.
There is two crowns betwixt you for your pains,
Sirrah, deliver them their stuff again,
And make them drink a cup of wine, farewell,
Good mistress Sanders let me leave the cloth,
I shall be chidden when I do come home.
And I, therefore I pray you be persuaded.
No no, I will excuse you to your masters.
So if you love me use no more entreaty.
I am a woman, and in that respect,
Am well content my husband shall control me,
But that my man should over-awe me too,
And in the sight of strangers, mistress Drurie:
I tell you true, does grieve me to the heart.
Your husband was to blame, to say the troth,
That gave his servant such authority,
What signifies it but he doth repose
More trust in a vild boy, than in his wife?
Nay, give me leave to think the best of him,
It was my destiny and not his malice,
Sure I did know as well when I did rise
This morning, that I should be chafed ere noon,
As where I stand.
By what, good mistress Sanders?
Why by these yellow spots upon my fingers,
They never come to me, but I am sure
To hear of anger ere I go to bed.
It is like enough, I pray you let me see,
Good sooth they are as manifest as day,
And let me tell you too, I see deciphered,
Within this palm of yours, to quite that evil,
Fair signs of better fortune to ensue,
Cheer up your heart, you shortly shall be free
From all your troubles. See you this character
Directly fixed to the line of life?
It signifies a dissolution,
You must be (mistress Anne) a widow shortly.
No, God forbid, I hope you do but jest.
It is most certain, you must bury George.
Have you such knowledge then in palmistry?
More than in surgery, though I do make
That my profession, this is my best living,
And where I cure one sickness or disease,
I tell a hundred fortunes in a year.
What makes my house so haunted as it is,
With merchants wives, bachelors and young maids,
But for my matchless skill in palmistry?
Lend me your hand again, I will tell you more.
A widow said I? yea, and make a change,
Not for the worse, but for the better far:
A gentleman (my girl) must be the next,
A gallant fellow, one that is beloved
Of great estates, it is plainly figured here,
And this is called the Ladder of Promotion.
I do not wish to be promoted so,
My George is gentle, and beloved beside,
And I have even as good a husband of him,
As any wench in London hath beside,
True, he is good, but not too good for God,
He is kind, but can his love dispense with death,
He is wealthy, and an handsome man beside,
But will his grave be satisfied with that?
He keeps you well, who says the contrary?
Yet better is better. Now you are arrayed
After a civil manner, but the next
Shall keep you in your hood, and gown of silk,
And when you stir abroad, ride in your coach,
And have your dozen men all in a livery
To wait upon you: this is somewhat like:
Yet had I rather be as now I am,
If God were pleased that it should be so,
Aye marry now you speak like a good christian,
If God were pleased: O but he hath decreed
It shall be otherwise, and to repine
Against his providence you know it is sin.
Your words do make me think I know not what,
And burden me with fear as well as doubt.
Tut, I could tell ye for a need, his name,
That is ordained to be your next husband,
But for a testimony of my former speeches,
Let it suffice I find it in your hand,
That you already are acquainted with him,
And let me see, this crooked line derived
From your ring finger shows me, not long since
You had some speech with him in the street,
Or near about your door I am sure it was.
I know of none more than that gentleman,
That supped with us, they call him captain Browne,
And he I must confess against my will,
Came to my door as I was sitting there,
And used some idle chat might have been spared
And more I wis than I had pleasure in,
I cannot tell, if captain Browne it were,
Then captain Browne is he must marry you.
His name is George I take it: yea it is so,
My rules of palmistry declare no less,
It is very strange how ye should know
so much,
Nay I can make rehearsal of the words,
Did pass betwixt you if I were disposed,
Yet I protest I never saw the man,
Since, nor before the night he supped with us,
Briefly, it is your fortune mistress Sanders,
And there is no remedy but you must leave him,
I counsel you to no immodesty
It is lawful, one deceased to take another.
In the mean space I would not have you coy,
But if he come unto your house, or so,
To use him courteously, as one for whom
You were created in your birth a wife.
If it be so, I must submit myself,
To that which God and destiny sets down:
But yet I can assure you mistress Drurie,
I do not find me any way inclined
To change off new affection, nor God willing
Will I be false to Sanders
whilst I live.
By this time he is returned from the Exchange,
Come, you shall sup with us.
I will follow you.
Why this is well, I never could have found
A fitter way to compass Brownes desire,
Nor in her woman's breast kindled loves fire.
For this will hammer so within her head,
As for the new, she will wish the old were dead,
When in the neck of this I will devise
Some stratagem to close up Sanders eyes.

stage.l: Enter Tragedy with a bowle of blood in her hand.

sp.l: Till now you have but sitten to behold,
The fatal entrance to our bloody scene,
And by gradations seen how we have grown
Into the maine stream of our tragedy:
All we have done, hath only been in words,
But now we come unto the dismal act,
And in these sable Curtains shut we up,
The Comic entrance to our direful play,
This deadly banquet is prepared at hand,
Where Ebony tapers are brought up from hell,
To lead black murther to this damned deed,
The ugly Screech-owl, and the night Raven,
With flaggy wings and hideous croaking noise.
Do beat the casements of this fatal house,
Whilst I do bring my dreadful furies forth,
To spread the table to this bloody feast.
Come forth and cover, for the time draws on,
Dispatch, I say, for now I must employ ye
To be the Ushers to this damned train.
Bring forth the banquet, and that lustful wine,
Which in pale mazers made of dead men's sculls,
They shall carouse to their destruction:
By this they are entered to this fatal door,
Hark how the ghastly fearful chimes of night
Do ring them in: and with a doleful peal

stage.l: Here some strange solemn music like bells

sp.l: Do fill the roof with sounds of tragedy:
Dispatch, I say, and be their Ushers in.

stage.l: The Furies go to the door and meet them: first
the Furies enter before leading them, dancing a soft
dance to the solemn music: next comes Lust before
Browne, leading mistress Sanders covered with a
black vail: Chastity all in white, pulling her back
softly by the arm: then Drewry, thrusting away Chastity,
Roger following: they march about, and then
sit to the table: the Furies fill wine, Lust drinks to
Browne, he to Mistress Sanders, she pledgeth him:
Lust embraceth her, she thrusteth Chastity from her,
Chastity wrings her hands, and departs: Drury and
whilst they sit down, Tragedy speaks.

sp.l: Here is the Mask unto this damned murther,
The Furies first, the devil leads the dance:
Next, lawless Lust conducteth cruel Browne,
He doth seduce this poor deluded soul,
Attended by unspotted Innocence,
As yet unguilty of her husbands death.
Next follows on that instrument of hell
That wicked Drurie, the accursed fiend,
That thrusts her forward to destruction,
And last of all is Roger, Druries man,
A villain expert in all treachery,
One conversant in all her damned drifts,
And a base broker in this murderous act.
Here they prepare them to these lustful feasts,
And here they sit all wicked murthers guests.

stage.l: Tragedy standing to behold them a while, till
the show be done, again turning

sp.l: Thus sin prevails, she drinks that poisoned draught,
With which base thoughts henceforth infects her soul,
And wins her free consent to this foul deed,
Now blood and Lust, both conquer and subdue,
And Chastity is quite abandoned:
Here enters Murther into all their hearts,
And doth possess them with the hellish thirst
Of guiltless blood: now will I make my chime
And lay this charming rod upon their eyes,
To make them sleep in their security.
Thus sits this poor soul, innocent of late,
Amongst these devils at this damned feast,
Won and betrayed to their detested sin,
And thus with blood their hands shall be imbrued,
Thy hands shall both be touched, for they alone
Are the foul actors of this impious deed:
And thine: and thine: for thou didst lay the plot,
And thou didst work this damned witch devise,
Your hands are both as deep in blood as his.
Only thou dippedest a finger in the same,
And here it is: Awake now when you will,
For now is the time wherein to work your ill.

stage.l: Here Browne starts up: draws his sword,

sp.l: Thus he is gone whilst they are all
secure,
Resolved to put these desperate thoughts in ure,
They follow him: and them will I attend,
Until I bring them all unto their end.

stage.l: Enter Sanders, and one or two with him.

sp.l: You see sir still I am a daily guest,
But with so true friends as I hold yourself,
I had rather be too rude, than too precise.
Sir this house is yours; you come but to your own,
And what else I call mine, is wholly yours,
So much I do endear your love sweet master Sanders,
A light ho, there.
Well sir at this time I will rather be unmannerly than
ceremonious
I will leave you sir to recommend my thanks,
Unto your kind respective wife.
Sir for your kind patience, she is much beholding to you
And I beseech you remember me to mistress Sanders.
Sir I thank you for her.
Sirrah, ho, who is within there?
Sir.
Light a Coach there, and wait on M. Sanders home
It shall not need sir, it is light enough.
Let it alone.
Nay, I pray ye sir.
i'faith sir at this time it shall not need,
It is very light, the streets are full of people,
And I have some occasion by the way that may detain
me.
Sir, I am sorry, that you go alone, it is
somewhat late,
It is well sir, God send you happy rest.
God bless you sir; passion of me, I had forgot one thing,
I am glad I thought of it before we parted:
Your patience sir a little.

stage.l: Here enters Browne speaking, in casting one side of his
under his arm. While master Sanders and he are in busy
talk one to the other, Browne steps to a corner.

sp.l: This way he should come, and a fitter place,
The town affords not, it is his nearest way,
And it is so late, he will not go about,
Then stand close George, and with a lucky arm,
Sluice out his life, the hinderer of thy love:
O sable night, sit on the eye of heaven,
That it discern not this black deed of darkness,
My guilty soul, burnt with lusts hateful fire,
Must wade through blood, to obtain my vile desire,
Be then my coverture, thick ugly night,
The light hates me, and I do hate the light,
Good night sir.
Good night good master Sanders.
Sir I shall see you on the Exchange tomorrow.
You shall God, willing Sir: good night.
I hear him coming fair unto my stand,
Murther and death sit on my fatal hand.

stage.l: Enters a Gentleman with a man with a torch before, Browne

sp.l: Who is there?
A friend.
Master Sanders? well met.
Good even gentle sir, so are you.
Where have you been so late sir?
A plague upon it, a light and company,
Even as I was about to do the deed.
See how the devil stumbles in the nick.
Sir, here at a friends of mine in Lumbered street
At supper: where I promise you,
Our cheer and entertainment was so great,
That we have past our hour:
Believe me sir the evening is stolen away,
I see it is later than I took it for.
Sirrah turn there at the corner since it is late,
I will go home with master Sanders.
No, I pray you sir trouble not yourself,
Sir I beseech you.
Sir pardon me, sirrah go on now where we are,
My way lies just with yours.
I am beholding to you.
Except by miracle, thou art delivered as was never man,
My sword unsheathed, and with the piercing steel,
Ready to broach his bosom, and my purpose
Thwarted by some malignant envious star.
Night I could stab thee, I could stab myself,
I am so mad that he scaped my hands.
Now like a fatal Comet did that light,
With this portentous vision fright mine eyes?
A mask of devils, walk along with thee,
And thou the torch bearer unto them all,
Thou fatal Brand never mayst thou be extinct,
Till thou hast set that damned house on fire,
Where he is lodged that brought thee to this place.
Sanders this hand doth hold that death alone,
And bears the seal of thy destruction:
Some other time shall serve till thou be dead,
My fortunes yet are near accomplished.

stage.l: Enter Master Barnes and Iohn Beane his man.

sp.l: Must I go first To Greenewich sir?
What else?
I cannot go by water, for it ebbs,
The wind is at west, and both are strong against us.
My meaning is that you shall go by land,
And come by water, though the tide be late,
Fail not to be at home again this night,
With answer of those letters which ye have.
This letter give to master Cofferer,
If he be not at court when ye come there,
Leave it at his chamber in any case,
Pray master Sanders to be here next week,
About the master at S. Marie Cray.
Methinks sir under your correction,
Next week is ill appointed.
Why, I pray ye?
It is Easter week, and every holiday,
Are sermons at the Spittle.
What of that?
Can master Sanders then be spared to come?
Well said Iohn fool, I hope at afternoon
A pair of Oars may bring him down to Wolwich,
Tell him he must come down in any wise.
What shall I bring from London?
A fools head.
A calves head is better meat,
It is Maundie thursday sir, and every butcher,
Now keeps open shop.
Well get ye gone, and hie ye home, how now?
What art thou drunk, canst thou not stand?
Yes sir, I did but stumble, God send me good luck
I was not wont to stumble on plain ground.
Look better to your feet then.
Yes forsooth: and yet I do not like it at my setting forth
They say it does betoken some mischance:
I fear not drowning if the boat be good,
There is no danger in so short a cut,
Betwixt Black Wall and Wolwich is the worst,
And if the watermen will watch the Anchors,
I will watch the catches and the boys myself,
Well I must go: Christs cross, God be my speed.

stage.l: Enter old Iohn, and Ioane his maid.

sp.l: Who comes there in Gods name? this woody way
Doth harbour many a false knave they say.
False knaves, ha? where be they? let me see
them, mass as old as I am, and have little skill, I will
hamper
a false knave yet in my hedging bill: stand these or true
man.
Master it is Iohn Beane.
Jesu Iohn Beane, why whither away by land?
What make you wandering this woody way?
Walk ye to Greenewich, or walk ye to Cray?
To Greenwich father Iohn, good morrow, good morrow
Good morrow Ioane, good morrow sweet to thee.
A thousand good morrows gentle Iohn Beane. I
am glad I met ye for now I have my dream, I have been
troubled with ye all this night, that I could not rest
for sleeping
and dreaming: methought you were grown taller and fatter,
and that ye were in your shirt, and methought it should
not be you, and yet it was you; and that ye were all in
white,
and went into a garden, and there was the umberest sort of
flowers that ever I see: and methought you lay down
a green bank, and I pinned gillyflowers in your ruff, and
then methought your nose bled, and as I ran to my chest
fetch ye a handkercher, methought I stumbled and so waked:
what does it betoken?
Nay, I cannot tell, but I like neither thy
dream nor my own, for I was troubled with green Meadows,
and bulls fighting and goring one another, and one of
them methought ran at me, and I ran away, that I sweat in
my sleep for fear.
Tut, fear nothing Iohn Beane, dreams are
but fancies: I dreamed myself last night, that I heard the
bells of Barking as plain to our town of Wolwich, as
if I
had line in the steeple. And that I should be married,
and to
whom trowest thou? but to the fine gentlewoman of London
that was at your masters the last summer?
Who? mistress Sanders? I shall see her anon, for
I have an errand to her husband: shall I tell her ye
dreamed
of her?
Gods forbid, no she will laugh at me, and call
me old fool. Art thou going to London?
Yea when I have been at the Court at Greenwich:
whither go you and your maid Ioane?
To stop a gap in my fence, and to drive home
a Cow and a Calf that is in my close, at Shooters
hill
foot.
It is well done, Mass I am merry since I met you
two, I would your journey lay along with mine.
So would I with all my heart. Iohn, pray ye bestow
a groat or six pence of Carnation Ribbon to tie my
smock sleeves, they flap about my hands too bad, and I
give you your money again.
That I will i'faith: will you have nothing, father
Iohn?
No God-a-mercy son Iohn, but I would
thou hadst my Aqua vitæ bottle, to fill at the black Bull
Battle bridge.
So would I: well, here our ways part, you must
that way, and I this.
Why, Iohn Beane, canst part with thy love
without a kiss?
Ye say true father Iohn, my business puts kissing
out of my mind, farewell sweet Ioane.
Farewell sweet Iohn, I pray ye have a care of yourself
for my dream, and bless ye out of swaggerers company,
and walk not too late, my master and I will pray for
ye.
That we will i'faith Iohn Beane.
God be with ye both: I could even
weep to see how
kind they are unto me, there is a wench, well, if I live I
will make
her amends.
Nay speak your conscience, was it not strange fortune
That at the instant when my sword was drawn,
And I had thought to have nailed him to a post,
A light should come, and so prevent my purpose?
It was so master Browne: but let it pass,
Another time shall serve, never give over
Till you have quite removed him out your way.
And if I do, let me be held a coward,
And no more worthy to obtain her bed,
Than a foul Negro to embrace a Queen.
You need not quail for doubt of your reward,
You know already she is won to this,
What by my persuasion, and your own suite,
That you may have her company when you will,
And she herself is thoroughly resolved,
None but George Browne must be her second husband.
The hope of that makes me anights to dream
Of nothing but the death of wretched Sanders,
Which I have vowed in secret to my soul
Shall not be long before that be determined.
But I do marvel that our scout returns not,
Trusty Roger whom we sent to dog him.
The knave is so careful (master Browne) of you,
As he will rather die than come again,
Before he find fit place to do the deed.
I am beholding both to you and him,
And mistress Drewry, I will requite your loves
By the mass see where the whoreson comes
Puffing and blowing, almost out of breath.
Roger how now, where hast thou been all day?
Where have I been? where I have had a jaunt,
Able to tire a horse.
But dost thou bring
Any good news where I may strike the stroke,
Shall make thyself and me amends for all?
That gather by the circumstance: first know,
That in the morning, till it was nine o'clock,
I watched at Sanders door till he came forth,
Then followed him to Cornhil, where he stayed
An hour talking in a merchants warehouse,
From thence he went directly to the Burse,
And there he walked another hour at least,
And I at his heels. By this it struck eleven,
Home then he comes to dinner, by the way
He chanced to meet a gentleman of the court,
With whom as he was talking, I drew near,
And at his parting from him heard him say,
That in the afternoon without all fail,
He would be with him at the court: this done
I watched him at his door till he had dined,
Followed him to Lion key, saw him take boat,
And in a pair of Oars, as soon as he
Landed at Greenewitch, where ever since,
I traced him to and fro, with no less care
Than I had done before, till at the last
I heard him call unto a water man,
And bade he should be ready, for by six
He meant to be at London back again.
With that away came I to give you notice,
That as he lands at Lion key this evening,
You might dispatch him and escape unseen.
Hodge, Thou hast won my heart by this days work
Beshrew me, but he hath taken mighty pains.
Roger come hither, there is for thee to drink,
And one day I will do thee greater good.
I thank you sir, Hodge is at your command.
Now mistress Drury, if you please, go home,
It is much upon the hour of his return.
Nay, I am sure he will be here straightaway.
Well, I will leave you, for it is somewhat late.
God speed your hand, and so master Browne good night.
Mistress I pray you spare me for this once,
I will be so bold as stay with Master Browne.
Do: and master Browne, if you prevail,
Come to my house, I will have a bed for you.
You shall have knowledge if I chance to speed,
But I will not lodge in London for a while,
Until the rumour shall be somewhat past:
Come Roger, where is it best to take our standing?
Marry at this corner, in my mind.
I like it well, it is dark and somewhat close,
By reason that the houses stand so near:
Beside, if he should land at Billingsgate,
Yet are we still betwixt his house and him.
You say well Master Browne, it is so indeed.
Peace then, no more words for being spied.

stage.l: Enter Anne Sanders, and Iohn Beane.

sp.l: I marvel Iohn thou sawest him not at court,
He hath been there ever since one o'clock.
Indeed mistress Sanders I heard not of him.
Pray God that captain Browne hath not been moved
By some ill motion, to endanger him,
I greatly fear it, he is so long away:
But tell me Iohn, must thou needs home tonight?
Yes of necessity, for so my Master bade.
If it be possible, I prithee stay
Until my husband come.
I dare not, trust me,
And I doubt that I have lost my tide already.
Nay that is not so: come, I will bring thee to
the key,
I hope we shall meet my husband by the way.
That should be mistress Sanders by her tongue.
It is my love, O how the dusky night
Is by her coming forth made sheen and bright:
I will know of her why she is abroad so late.
Take heed master Browne, see where Sanders comes.
A plague upon it, now am I prevented,
She being by, how can I murther him?
Your fare is but eighteen pence, here is a half-a-crown
I thank your worship, God give ye good night
Good night with all my heart.
O here he is now:
Husband, ye are welcome home: now Jesu man
That you will be so late upon the water?
My business, sweet heart, was such I could not choose
Here is M. Barnses man hath staid all day to speak to
you.
Iohn Beane, welcome, how is it?
How doth thy master, and all our friends at Wolwich?
All in good health (sir) when I came thence.
And what is the news, Iohn Beane?
My Master (sir) requests you, that upon tuesday
next you would take the pains to come down to Wolwich,
about the matter you wot of.
Well Iohn, tomorrow thou shalt know my mind.
Nay sir, I must to Wolwich by this tide.
What tonight? there is no such haste, I hope.
Yes truly (with your pardon) it must be so.
Well then, if Iohn you will be gone, commend me
to your Master, and tell him, without fail on tuesday
sometime
of the day I will see him, and so good night.
Commend me likewise to thy master Iohn.
I thank you mistress Sanders for my cheer,
Your commendations shall be delivered.
I would thyself and he were both sent hence
To do a message to the devil of hell,
For interrupting this my solemn vow,
But questionless some power or else prayer
Of some religious friend or other guards him,
Or else my sword is unfortunate, it is so,
This metal was not made to kill a man.
Good master Browne fret not yourself so much,
Have you forgot what the old proverb is,
The third time pays for all? Did you not hear,
That he sent word to master Barnes of Woolwich,
He would be with him as on tuesday next:
Twixt that and then lie you in wait for him
And though he have escaped your hand so oft,
You may be sure to pay him home at last.
Fury had almost made me past myself,
It is well remembered: Hodge, it so shall be,
Some place will I pick out as he does pass,
Either in going or in coming back,
To end his hateful life: come let us away,
And at thy mistress house we will spend this night,
In consultation how it may be wrought.
Twice (as you see) this sad distressed man,
The only mark whereat foul Murther
shot:
Just in the loose of envious eager death,
By accidents strange and miraculous,
Escaped the arrow aimed at his heart.
Suppose him on the water now for Woolwich,
For secrete business with his bosom friend,
From thence, as fatal destiny conducts him,
To Mary-Cray by some occasion called:
Which by false Druries means made known to Browne,
Lust, Gain, and Murther spurred this villain on,
Still to pursue this unsuspecting soul,
And now the dreadful hour of death is come,
The dismal morning when the destinies,
Do shear the labouring vital thread of life,
When as the lamb left in the woods of Kent,
Unto this ravenous wolf becomes a pray,
Now of his death the general intent,
Thus Tragedy doth to your eyes present.

stage.l: The Music playing, enters Lust bringing forth Browne and
Roger, at one end mistress Sanders and mistress Drurie at
the other, they offering cheerfully to meet and embrace,
suddenly riseth up a great tree between them, whereat
they step back, whereupon Lust bringeth an axe
to mistress Sanders, showing signs, that she should cut
down, which she refuseth, albeit mistress Drurie offers
help her. Then Lust brings the Axe to Browne, and shows
the like signs to him as before, whereupon he roughly
suddenly hews down the tree, and then they run together
and embrace. With that enters Chastity, with her
dishevelled, and taking mistress Sanders by the hand, brings
her to her husbands picture hanging on the wall,
pointing to the tree, seems to tell her, that
rashly cut down. Whereupon she wringing her hands,
in tears departs, Browne, Drurie, Roger and Lust,
he draws his sword, and Roger follows him. Tragedy
expressing that now he goes to act the deed.

sp.l: Lust leaves together this adulterous route,
But as you see are hindered thus, before
They could attain unto their foul desires.
The tree springs up, whose body whilst
it stands,
Still keeps them back when they would fain embrace,
Whereat they start, for fury evermore
Is full replete with fear and envy.
Lust giveth her the Axe to cut it down,
To rid her husband whom it represents,
In which this damned woman would assist her.
But though by them seduced to consent,
And had a finger in her husbands blood;
Could not be won to murther him herself.
Lust brings the Axe to Browne, who suddenly.
Doth give the fatal stroke unto the tree,
Which being done, they then embrace together:
The act performed, now Chastity appears,
And pointing to the picture, and the tree,
Unto her guilty conscience, shows her husband,
Even so cut off by that vile murtherer Browne,
She wrings her hands repenting of the fact,
Touched with remorse, but now it is too late.
What is here expressed, in act is to be done,
The sword is drawn, the murtherer forth doth run,
Lust leads him on, he follows him with speed,
The only actor in this damned
deed.

stage.l: Enter Browne reading a Letter, and Roger.

sp.l: Did I but waver, or were unresolved,
These lines were able to encourage me,
Sweet Nan I kissed thy name, and for thy sake,
What coward would not venture more than this
Kill him? Yea, were his life ten thousand lives,
Not any spark or cinder of the same
Should be unquenched in blood at thy request.
Roger thou art assured he will come this way.
Assured sir? why I heard him say so:
For having lodged at Wolwich, all last night,
As soon as day appeared, I got me up,
And watched aloof at master Barnses door,
Till he and master Sanders both came forth.
Till both came forth? what are they both together?
No sir, master Barnes himself went back again,
And left his man to bear him company,
Iohn Beane: you know him, he that was at London
When we laid wait for him at Billingsgate.
Is it that stripling? well, no more ado,
Roger go thou unto the hedge corner
At the hill foot: there stand and cast thine eye
Toward Greenwich park, see if black heath be clear,
Least by some passenger we be descried.
Shall ye not need my help sir? they are twain.
No, were they ten, mine arm is strong enough
Even of itself to buckle with them all,
And ere George Sanders shall escape me now,
I will not reck what massacre I make,
Well sir, I will go and watch, and when I see
Anybody coming, I will whistle
to you.
Do so I prithee: I would be alone,
My thoughts are studious and unsociable,
And so is my body, till this deed be done.
But let me see, what time of day is it now?
It cannot be imagined by the sun,
For why I have not seen it shine today,
Yet as I gather by my coming forth,
Being then five, it cannot now be less
Than half an hour past seven: the air is gloomy,
No matter, darkness best fits my intent,
Here will I walk, and after shroud myself
Within those bushes when I see them come.

stage.l: Enter Master Sanders and Iohn Beane.

sp.l: Iohn Beane, this is the right way, is it not?
Aye sir, would to God we were past this wood.
Why art thou afraid? See yonder is company.
They have espied me, I will slip aside.
O God sir, I am heavy at the heart.
Good master Sanders let us return back to Wolwich,
Methinks I go this way against my will.
Why so I prithee?
Truly I do not like
The man we saw, he slipped so soon away,
behind the bushes.
Trust me Iohn, nor I,
But yet God willing we will keep our way.
I pray you sir let us go back again,
I do remember now a dream was told me,
That might I have the world I cannot choose
But tremble every joint to think upon it,
But we are men, let us not be so faint-hearted,
As to affright ourselves with visions,
Come on in Gods name.

stage.l: Browne steps out and strikes up Iohns heels

sp.l: O we are undone.
What seek you sir?
Thy blood which I will have.
O take my money, and preserve my life.
It is is not millions that can ransom thee,
Nor this base drudge, for both of you must die.
Hear me a word, you are a gentleman,
Soil not your hands with blood of innocents.
Thou speakest in vain.
Then God forgive my sin,
Have mercy on me, and upon thee too,
The bloody author of my timeless death.
Now will I dip my hankercherchief in his blood,
And send it as a token to my love,
Look how many wounds my hand hath given him,
So many holes I will make within this cloth.
Jesu receive my soul into thy hands.
What sound was that? it was not he that spake
The breath is banished, from his nostrils,
Was it the other? no, his wounds are such,
As he is likewise past the use of speech.
Who was it then that thundered in mine ears,
The name of Jesu? Doubtless it was my conscience,
And I am damned for this unhallowed deed.
O sin how hast thou blinded me till now,
Promising me security and rest,
But givest me dreadful agony of soul?
What shall I do? or whither shall I fly?
The very bushes will discover me.
See how their wounds do gape unto the skies,
Calling for vengeance.
How now master Browne?
What have you done? why so, let us away,
For I have spied come riding over the heath,
Some half-a-dozen in a company.
Away to London thou, I will to the Court,
And show myself, and after follow thee,
Give this to mistress Sanders, bid her read
Upon this bloody handkercher the thing,
As I did promise and have now performed,
But were it Roger to be done again,
I would not do it for a kingdoms gain.
Tut faint not now, come let us haste away.
O I must fear, whatever thou
dost say.
My shadow, if nought else will me betray.

stage.l: Beane left wounded, and for dead, stirs and creeps.

sp.l: Dare I look up, for fear he yet be near
That thus hath martyred me? yea, the coast is clear:
For all these deadly wounds, yet lives my heart,
Alack, how loath poor life is from my limbs to part!
I cannot go, ah no, I cannot stand,
O God that some good body were near hand:
To help me home to Wolwich ere I die,
To creep that wayward whilst I live I will try:
O could I crawl but from this cursed wood,
Before I drown myself in my own blood.
Now by my fathers saddle Ioane I think we
are bewitched, my beasts were never wont to break out
often: sure as death the harlotries are bespoken: but it is
heifer with the white back that leads them all agadding,
a
good luck take her.
It is not dismal day master? did ye look
in the Amminicke? if it be not, then it is either long of
the
branded cow, that was never well in her wits since
the butcher
bought her calf, or long of my dream, or of my nose
bleeding
this morning, for as I was washing my hands my nose bled
three drops, then I thought of Iohn Bean, God be with him,
for I dreamed he was married, and that our white
calf was
killed for his wedding dinner, God blesse them both, for I
love
them both well.
Marie amen, for I tell thee my heart is heavy,
God send me good luck: my eyes dazzle, and I could weep.
Lord bless us, what sight is this? look Ione, and cross
thyself.
O master, master, look in my purse for a piece of ginger,
I shall swab, I shall swoon, cut my lace, and cover my
face, I die else, it is Iohn Beane, killed, cut, slain:
master,
if ye be a man, help.
Iohn Beane? Now Gods forbid, alike alack
good Iohn, how came ye in this piteous plight? speak good
Iohn, nay groan not, speak who has done this deed? thou
hast not foredone thyself, hast thou?
Ah no, no.
Ah, no, no, he need not have done that, for God
knows I loved him as dearly as he loved me, speak Iohn,
who did it?
One in a white doublet and blue breeches, he has
slain another too, not far off: O stop my wounds if ye
can.
Ioane, take my napkin and thy apron, and
bind up his wounds, and cows go where they will till
we have
carried him home.
Woe worth him Iohn that did this dismal deed,
Heart-break be his mirth, and hanging be his meed.
Ah welladay, see where another lies, a handsome
comely ancient gentleman: what an age live we in?
when men have no mercy of men more than of dogs, bloodier
than beasts? This is the deed of some swaggering, swearing,
drunken desperate Dicke. Call we them Cavaliers?
mass they be Cannibals, that have the stabs readier
their hands than a penny in their purse: Shames death be
their share. Ione, hast thou done? Come lend me a hand, to
lay this good man in some bush, from birds and from beasts,
till we carry home Iohne Beane to his Masters, and
raise all
Wolwich to fetch home this man, and make search: lift there
Ione; so, so.
Lord comfort my soul, my body is past cure.
Now let us take up Iohn Beane:
Softly Ione, softly.
Ah Iohn, little thought I to have carried thee thus
within this week, but my hope is asleep, and my joy is laid
to sleep.

stage.l: Enter a yeoman of the Buttery, Browne, and master Iames.

sp.l: Welcome master Browne, what is it you will drink,
ale or beer?
Marry ale and if you please,
You see sir I am bold to trouble you.
No trouble sir at all, the Queen our Mistress
Allows this bounty to all comers, much more
To Gentlemen of your sort: some ale there ho.

stage.l: Enter one with a Iacke and court dish.

sp.l: Here master Browne, thus much to your health.
I thank you sir: nay, prithee fill my cup.
Here master Iames, to you with all my heart.
How say you now sir? was I not adry?
Believe me yes, will it please ye mend your draught?
No more sir in this heat, it is not good.
It seems, master Browne, that you have
gone apace.
Came you from London that you made such haste?
But soft, what have I spied? your hose is bloody.
How, bloody? where? Good sooth it is so indeed.
It seems it is but newly done.
No more it is:
And now I do remember how it came,
Myself, and some two or three Gentlemen more
Crossing the field this morning here from Eltham
Chanced by the way to start a brace of hares,
One of the which we killed, the other scaped,
And pulling forth the garbage, this befell:
But it is no matter, it will out again.
Yes there is no doubt, with a little soap and water.
I would I had been with you at that sport,
I would you had sir, it was good sport indeed.
Now before God, this blood was ill
espied?
But my excuse I hope will serve the turn.
Gentlemen, I must to London this forenoon,
About some earnest business both concern me,
Thanks for my ale, and your good companies.
Adieu good master Browne.
Farewell unto you both.
An honest proper Gentleman as lives:
God be with you sir, I will up into the Presence.
Ye are welcome M. James, God be with ye sir.

stage.l: Enter Anne Sanders, Anne Drewry, and Roger: Drewry
having the bloody handkercher in her hand.

sp.l: O show not me that ensign of despair,
But hide it, burn it, bury it in the earth,
It is a calendar of bloody letters,
Containing his, and yours, and all our shames.
Good mistress Sanders, be not so outrageous.
What tell you me? is not my husband slain?
Are not we guilty of his cruel death?
O my dear husband I will follow thee:
Give me a knife, a sword, or anything,
Wherewith I may do justice on myself.
Justice for murther, justice for the death
Of my dear husband, my betrothed love.
These exclamations will bewray us all,
Good mistress Sanders peace.
I pray you peace,
Your servants, or some neighbours else will hear.
Shall I fear more my servants, or the world,
Than God himself? He heard our treachery,
And saw our complot and conspiracy:
Our heinous sin cries in the ears of him,
Louder than we can cry upon the earth:
A woman's sin, a wives inconstancy,
O God that I was born to be so vile,
So monstrous and prodigious for my lust.
Fie on this pride of mine, this pampered flesh,
I will revenge me on these ticing eyes,
And tear them out for being amorous.
O Sanders my dear husband, give me leave,
Why do you hold me? are not my deeds ugly?
Let then my faults be written in my face.
O do not offer violence to yourself.
Have I not done so already? Is not
The better part of me by me misdone?
My husband, is he not slain? is he not dead?
But since you labour to prevent my grief,
I will hide me in some closet of my house,
And there weep out mine eyes, or pine to death,
That have untimely stopped my husbands breath.
What shall we do Roger? go thou and watch
For master Brownes arrival from the Court,
And bring him hither, happily his presence
Will be a means to drive her from this passion.
In the mean space I will go after her,
And do the best I can to comfort her.
I will: take heed she do not kill herself.
For Gods sake haste thee, and be circumspect.

stage.l: Enter Sanders young son, and another boy

sp.l: Come Harrie shall we play a game?
At what?
Why at cross and pile.
You have no Counters.
Yes but I have as many as you.
I will drop with you, and he that has most, take all.
No sir, if you will play a game, it is not yet twelve
by half an hour, I will set you like a gamester.
Go to, where shall we play?
Here at our door.
What and if your father find us?
No he is at Woolwich, and will not come
home tonight.
Set me then, and here is a good.
Is she so out of patience as thou sayst?
Wonderful sir, I have not seen the like.
What does she mean by that? nay what mean I
To ask the question? has she not good cause?
O yes, and we have every one of us just cause
To hate and be at variance with ourselves.
But come, I long to see her.
How now captain?
Why stop you on the sudden? why go you not?
What makes you look so ghastly towards the house?
Is not the foremost of those pretty boys
One of George Sanders sons?
Yes, it is his youngest.
Both youngest and eldest are now made fatherless
By my unlucky hand. I prithee go,
And take him from the door, the sight of him
Strikes such a terror to my guilty conscience,
As I have not the heart to look that way,
Nor stir my foot until he be removed.
Methinks in him I see his fathers wounds
Fresh bleeding in my sight, nay he doth stand
Like to an Angel with a fiery sword,
To bar mine entrance at that fatal door,
I prithee steppe, and take him quickly thence.
Away my pretty boy, your master comes,
And you will be taken playing in the street,
What at unlawful games? away be gone,
It is dinner time, young Sanders you will be jerked,
Your mother looks for you before this time.
Gaffer if you will not tell my master of me,
I will give you this new silk point.
Go to I will not.
Nor of me, and there is two counters, I have
won no more.
Of neither of you, so you will be gone.
God be with you, ye shall see me no more.
Nor me, I mean playing at this door.
Now captain if you please you may come forward
But see where mistress Sanders and my mistress
Are coming forth to meet you on the way?
See where master Browne is, in him take comfort,
And learn to temper your excessive grief.
Ah, bid me feed on poison and be fat,
Or look upon the Basilisk and live,
Or surfeit daily and be still in health,
Or leap into the sea and not be drowned:
All these are even as possible as this,
That I should be recomforted by him,
That is the Author of my whole lament.
Why mistress Anne I love you dearly,
And but for your incomparable beauty
My soul had never dreamt of Sanders death:
Then give me that which now I do deserve,
Yourself, your love, and I will be to you
A husband so devote, as none more just,
Or more affectionate shall tread this earth.
If you can crave it of me with a tongue
That hath not been profaned with wicked vows,
Or think it in a heart did never harbour
Pretence of murther, or put forth a hand
As not contaminate with shedding blood,
Then will I willingly grant your request:
But o your hand, your heart, your tongue, and eye,
Are all presenters of my misery.
Talk not of that, but let us study now
How we may salve it, and conceal the fact.
Mountains will not suffice to cover it,
Cymerian darkness cannot shadow it,
Nor any policy wit hath in store,
Cloak it so cunningly, but at the last
If nothing else, yet will the very stones
That lie within the streets cry out for vengeance,
And point at us to be the murderers.

stage.l: Enter three Lords, Master Iames, and two Messengers
with their boxes, one Lord reading a letter.

sp.l: Fore God (my Lords) a very bloody act.
Yea, and committed in eye of Court
Audaciously, as who should say, he durst
Attempt a murther in despite of Law.
Pray ye let us see your letter (good my Lord.)

stage.l: He takes and reads the letter.

sp.l: Ten wounds at least, and deadly every
wound,
And yet he lives, and tells marks of the man,
Even at the edge of the Shooters hill,
so near?
We shall not need to send these Messengers,
For hew and cry may take the murtherers.

stage.l: Enter a fourth Lord with a Water man and a Page.

sp.l: Nay sirrah you shall tell this tale again
Before the Lords, come on: my Lords what news?
Bad news my Lord, A cruel murther is done,
Near Shooters hill, and here is a letter come
From Wolwich, from a gentleman of worth,
Noting the manner, and the marks of him,
(By likelihood) that did that impious deed.
It is noised at London, that a merchant is slain,
One master Sanders dwelling near Tames street,
And that George Browne, a man whom we all know,
Is vehemently suspected for the fact,
And fled upon it, and this same water man,
That brought me down says he rowed him up,
And that his hose were bloody, which he hid
Still with his hat sitting bare head in the boat,
And sighed and stared as one that was afraid,
Now sayst thou sirrah, was it not so he did?
Yes, if it please your Lordship so it was.
What did he wear?
A doublet of white satin,
And a large pair of breeches of blue silk.
Was he so suited when you drank with him,
Here in the buttery?
Yea my Lord he was.
And his hose bloody?
Just as he affirms.
Confer the marks the wounded fellow tells
with these reports.
The man that did the deed,
Was fair and fat, his doublet of white silk,
His hose of blue, I am sorry for George Browne.
It was he my Lords.
The more accursed man,
Get warrants drawn: and messengers attend,
Call all your fellows, ride out every way,
Post to the Ports, give charge that no man pass
Without our warrant, one take boat to London,
Command the Sheriffs make wise and speedy search,
Decipher him by all the marks you can,
Let blood be paid with blood in any man.
We were to blame else: come my lords, let us
in,
To sign our warrants, and to send them out.

stage.l: Enter Drury, and Roger with a bagge.

sp.l: Why Roger, canst thou get but twenty pound,
Of all the plate that thou hadst from us both,
Mine own is worth twenty, what hadst thou of her?
Two bowls and spoons I know not what myself.
It is in a note, and I could get no more
But twenty pound.
Alas it will do no good.
And he must thence, if he be taken he dies,
On his escape thou knowest our safety lies.
That is true, alas what will ye have me do?
Run to Nan Sanders bid her make her some shift,
Try all her friends to help at this dead lift:
For all the money that she can devise,
And send by thee with all the haste she may,
Tell her we die if Browne make any stay.
I will I will.
Thou wilt, thou wilt, alas
That ere this dismal deed was brought to pass,
But now it is done, we must prevent the worst.
And here comes he that makes us all accursed:
How now George Browne?
Nan Drurie now undone.
Undone by that, that thou hast made me do.
I make ye do it? your own love made ye do it.
Well, done it is, what shall we now say to it,
Search is made for me, be I taken, I die,
And there are other as far in as I.
I must beyond sea, money have I none,
Nor dare I look for any of mine own.
Here is twenty pound I borrowed of my plate,
And to your Mistress I have sent for more
By Hodge my man: now Roger, hast thou sped?
Yea, of six pound, it is all that she can make,
She prays ye take it in worth, and to be gone:
She hears the Sheriffs will be there anon,
And at our house: a thousand commendations
She sends you, praying you to shift for yourself.
Even as I may Roger, farewell to thee,
If I were richer, then thou shouldst go with me,
But poverty parts company, farewell Nan,
Commend me to my mistress if you can.
Step thither yourself, I dare not come there,
I will keep my house close, for I am in fear.
God be with you good Captain.
Farewell, gentle Hodge,
O master Sanders, wert thou now alive,
All Londons wealth thy death should not contrive:
This heat of love and hasty climbing breeds,
God bless all honest tall men from such deeds.
Prevailing Sin having by three degrees,
Made his ascension to forbidden deeds,
As first, alluring their unwary minds
To like what she proposed, then practising
To draw them to consent: and last of all
Ministering fit means and opportunity
To execute what she approved good:
Now she unveils their sight, and lets them see
The horror of their foul immanity
And wrath that all this while hath been obscured,
Steps forth before them in a thousand shapes
Of ghastly thoughts, and loathing discontents:
So that the rest was promised, now appears
Unrest, and deep affliction of the soul,
Delight proves danger, confidence despair,
As by this following show shall more appear.

stage.l: Enter Justice and Mercy: when having taken their seats,
falls into a slumber, then enters wronged Chastity, and
in dumb action uttering her grief to Mercy, is put
whereon she wakens Justice, who listening her
starts up, commanding his Officers to attend her.
they with her, and fetch forth master Sanders body, mistress
Sanders, Drury, and Roger, led after it, and being shown it,
they all seem very sorrowful, and so are led away. But
shows that the chief offender is not as yet taken,
whereon Justice dispatcheth his servant Diligence to make
further enquiry after the murderer, and so they depart the

sp.l: Thus lawless actions and prodigious crimes
Drink not the blood alone of them they hate,
But even their ministers, when they have done
All that they can, must help to fill the Scene,
And yield their guilty necks unto the block.
For which intent, the wronged Chastity
Prostrate before the sacred throne of Justice,
With wringing hands, and cheeks besprent with tears,
Pursues the murtherers. And being heard
Of Mercy first, that in relenting words,
Would fain persuade her to humility,
She turns from her: and with her tender hand
Makes slumbering Justice, when her tale being told,
And the dead body brought for instance forth,
Strait inquisition and search is made,
And the offenders as you did behold,
Discovered where they thought to be unseen.
Then trial now remains as shall conclude,
Measure for measure, and lost blood for blood.

stage.l: Enter George Browne, and one Browne a

sp.l: It is marvel cousin Browne we see you here,
And thus alone without all company:
You were not wont to visit Rochester,
But you had still some friend or other with you.
Such is the occasion cousin at this time,
And for the love I bear you, I am bold
To make myself your guest, rather than lie
In any public Inn: because indeed
The house where I was wont to host, is full
Of certain Frenchmen and their followers.
Nay cousin Browne, I would not have you think
I do object thus much as one unwilling
To show you any kindness that I can,
My house though homely, yet such as it is,
And I myself will be at your command.
I love you for your name sake, and trust me sir,
Am proud that such a one as you will call me cousin,
Though I am sure we are no kin at all.
Yes cousin we are kin: nor do I scorn
At any time to acknowledge as much,
Toward men of baser calling than yourself.
It may be so sir: but to tell you truth,
It seemed somewhat strange to me at first,
And I was half afraid some ill had happened,
That made you careful whom you trusted to.
Faith cousin none but this: I owe some money,
And one I am indebted to of late,
Hath brought this action to an outlawry
And seeks to do me all extremity,
But that I am not yet provided for him,
And that he shall not have his will of me,
I do absent me, till a friend of mine
Do see what order he may take with him.
How now who is this?

stage.l: Enter master Mayor, master Iames, with a

sp.l: Where are you neighbour Browne?
Master Mayor, ye are welcome, what is the news sir
You come so guarded, is there aught amiss?
Heaven will have justice shown, it is even so.
I can assure you it is the man we seek,
Then do your office master Mayor.
George Browne.
I do arrest you in her highness name,
As one suspected to have murdered
George Sanders Citizen of London.
Of murther sir? there lives not in this land
Can touch me with the thought of murther.
Pray God it be so: but you must along
Before their honours there to answer it.
Here is a commission that commands it so.
Well sir I do obey, and do not doubt
But I shall prove me innocent therein.
Come master Mayor, it is the Council's pleasure,
You must assist us till we come to Woolwich,
Where we have order to confer at large
With master Barnes concerning this mishap.
Withal my heart, farewell good neighbour Brown.
God keep you master Mayor, and all the rest.
And master Browne believe me I am sorry
It was your fortune to have no more grace.
Cousin grieve not for me, my case is clear,
Suspected men may be, but need not fear.

stage.l: Enter Iohn Beane brought in a Chair, and master

sp.l: Sir how much I esteemed this Gentleman,
And in how hie respect I held his love,
My griefs can hardly utter.
It shall not need, your love after his death
expresses it.
I would to god it could: and I am very
glad,
My Lords of her most honourable Council
Have made choice of yourself, so grave a gentleman
To see the manner of this cruel murther.
Sir, the most unworthy I of many men,
But that in the hie bounty of your kindness, so you
term me.
But trust me master Barnes, amongst the rest
That was reported to them of the murther,
They hardly were induced to believe,
That this poor soul having so many wounds,
And all so mortal as they were reported,
With so much loss of blood, should possibly yet live:
Why it is past belief.
Sir it is so, your worthy self can witness.
As strange to us that look upon the wretch,
As the report thereof unto their wisdoms.
More fearful wounds, nor hurts more dangerous,
Upon my faith I have not seen.
Hey ho, a little drink, o my head.
Good Iohn how dost thou?
Who is that? father Iohn?
Nay Iohn, thy master.
O Lord my belly.
He spends more breath; that issues through his wounds,
than through his lips.
I am dry.
Iohn dost thou know me?
See where thy master is: look dost thou know him?
Sir he never had his perfect memory, since the first hour
Surely he cannot last.
And yet sir to our seeming I assure you,
He sat not up so strongly, as you see him
Since he was brought into this house as now.
It is very strange.

stage.l: Enter the Mayor of Rochester, with Browne,

sp.l: As I take it, master Mayor of Rochester?
The same good master Barnes.
What happy fortune sent you here to Woolwich:
That yet your company may give us comfort, in this
sad time?
Believe me sad indeed, and very sad,
Sir the Council's warrant lately came to me
About the search, for one Captain George Browne,
As it should seem suspected for this murther,
Whom in my search I happed to apprehend.
And hearing that the bodies of the murdered
Remained here, I thought it requisite,
To make this in my way to the Court,
Now going thither with the prisoner.
Believe me sir ye have done right good service.
And shown yourself a painful Gentleman,
And shall no doubt deserve well of the state.
No doubt you shall, and I durst assure you, so
The Council will accept well of the same.
Good master Mayor this wretched man of mine,
Is not yet dead: look you where he sits,
But past all sense, and labouring to his end.
Alas poor wretch.
Is this that Browne that is suspected to have done
The murther? a goodly man believe me.
Too fair a creature for so foul an act.
My name is Browne sir.
I know you well, your fortunes have been
Fair, as any Gentleman's of your repute.
But Browne, should you be guilty of this fact,
As this your flight hath given shrewd suspicion,
O Browne, your hands have done the bloodiest deed
That ever was committed.
He doth not live dare charge me with it.
Pray God there be not.
