Sergeants bring him near: see if this poor soul
know him.
It cannot be: these two days space
He knew no creature.
'swounds, lives the villain yet?
O how his very sight affrights my soul!
His very eyes will speak had he no tongue,
And will accuse me.
See how his wounds break out afresh in bleeding.
He stirs himself.
He openeth his eyes.
See how he looks upon him.
I gave him fifteen wounds,
Which now be fifteen mouths that do accuse me,
In every wound there is a bloody
tongue,
Which will all speak, although he hold his peace,
By a whole Jury I shall be accused.
Iohn, dost thou hear? knowest thou this man?
Yea, this is he that murdered me and M. Sanders.
O hold him up.
Iohn comfort thyself.
Bow him, give him air.
No he is dead.
Methinks he is so fearful in my sight,
That were he now but where I saw him last,
For all this world I would not look on him.
The wondrous work of God, that the poor
creature, not speaking for two days, yet now should speak
to accuse this man, and presently yield up his soul.
It is very strange, and the report thereof
Can seem no less unto the Lords.
Sergeants, away, prepare you for the court,
And I will follow you immediately.
Sure the revealing of this murther is strange.
It is so sir: but in the case of blood,
Gods justice hath been still miraculous.
I have heard it told, that digging by a grave,
Wherein a man had twenty years been buried,
By finding of a nail knocked in the scalp,
By due enquiry who was buried there,
The murther yet at length did come to light.
I have heard it told, that once a traveller,
Being in the hands of him that murdered him,
Told him, the fern that then grew in the place,
If nothing else, yet that would sure reveal him:
And seven years after, being safe in London,
There came a sprig of fern borne by the wind,
Into the room where as the murtherer was,
At sight whereof he suddenly start up,
And then revealed the murder.
I will tell you (sir) one more to quite your tale,
A woman that had made away her husband,
And sitting to behold a tragedy
At Linne a town in Norffolke,
Acted by players travelling that way,
Wherein a woman that had murdered hers
Was ever haunted with her husbands ghost:
The passion written by a feeling pen,
And acted by a good Tragedian,
She was so moved with the sight thereof,
As she cried out, the Play was made by her,
And openly confessed her husbands murder.
However theirs, Gods name be
praised for this
You M. Mayor I see must to the Court:
I pray you do my duty to the Lords.
That will I sir.
Come, I will go along with you.

stage.l: Enter the Lords at the Court, and Messengers.

sp.l: Where was Browne apprehended, Messenger?
At Rochester (my Lord) in a Butchers house
of his own name, from thence brought up to Wolwich.
And there the fellow he left for dead with all
those wounds affirmed that it was he.
He did my Lord, and with a constant voice, prayed
God forgive Browne, and receive his soul, and so departed.
It is a wondrous thing.
But that the power of heaven sustained him,
A man with nine or ten such mortal wounds,
Not taking food should live so many days,
And then at sight of Browne recover strength,
And speak so cheerily as they say he did.
Aye, and soon after he avouched the fact
Unto Brownes face then to give up the ghost.
It was Gods good will it should be so my Lord,
But what said Browne, did he deny the deed?
Never my Lord, but did with tears lament,
(As seems to us) his heinous cruelty.
When will they come?
Immediately my Lord,
For they have wind, and tide, and boats do wait.
My Lords, the Mayor of Rochester is come
with Browne.
Let him come in: you messenger,
Haste you to London to the Justices,
Will them from us see and indictment drawn,
Against George Browne for murdering of George Sanders.
Welcome good master Mayor of Rochester.

stage.l: Enter Mayor, Browne, a Messenger, another, and M. Humpherie

sp.l: I humbly thank your honours.
We thank you.
For your great care and diligence in this,
And many other faithful services.
Now master Browne, I am sorry it was your hap,
To be so far from grace and fear of God,
As to commit so bloody a murder,
What say ye? are ye not sorry for it?
Yes my Lord, and were it now to do,
All the worlds wealth could not entice me to it.
Was there any ancient quarrel Browne,
Betwixt yourself and master Sanders?
No.
Was it for the money that he had about him?
No my good Lord I knew of none he had.
No, I heard an inkling of the cause,
You did affect his wife George Browne too much.
I did my Lord, and God forgive it me.
Then she provoked ye to dispatch him.
No.
Yes, and promised you should marry her.
No, I will take it upon my death.
Some other were confederate in the fact,
Confess then Browne, discharge thy conscience.
I will my Lord at hour of my death.
Nay now that they with thee may die for it.
From whom is this letter?
From the Sheriffs at London.
I told ye mistress Sanders hand was in.
The act is confessed by two that she knew of it.
They do her wrong my Lords upon my life,
Why Druries wife and Roger do affirm,
Unto her face that she did give consent.
God pardon them, they wrong the innocent,
They both are guilty and procured the deed,
And gave me money since the deed was done,
Twenty-six pound to carry me away,
But mistress Sanders as I hope for heaven,
Is guiltless, ignorant how it was done,
But Druries wife did bear me still in hand,
If he were dead she would effect the marriage,
And trusty Roger her base apple-squire
Haunted me like a sprite till it was done,
And now like Devils accuse that harmless soul.
Well M. Browne, we are sorry for your fall,
You were a man respected of us all,
And noted sir for many services,
And fie that wanton lust should overthrow
Such gallant parts in any Gentleman:
Now all our favours cannot do ye good,
The act is too odious to be spoken of,
Therefore we must dismiss ye to the Law.
Expect no life, but meditate of death,
And for the safeguard of thy sinful soul,
Conceal no part of truth for friend or foe.
And master Mayor, as you have taken pains,
So finish it, and see him safe conveyed
To the Justices of the Bench at Westminster:
Will them from us to try him speedily,
That Gentleman shall go along with you,
And take in writing his confession.
Farewell George Browne, discharge thy conscience.
I do my Lord, that Sanders wife is clear.

stage.l: Enter some to prepare the judgment seat to the Lord
Lo. Justice, and the four Lords, and one Clerk, and a
who being set, command Browne to be brought forth.

sp.l: Come let us make haste, and well prepare this place.
How well I pray you? what haste more than was wont.
Why divers lords are come from court today.
To see the arraignment of this lusty Browne.
Lusty? how lusty? now he is tame enough,
And will be tamer. O a lusty youth,
Lustily fed, and lustily apparelled,
Lusty in look, in gate, in gallant talk,
Lusty in wooing, in fight and murdering,
And lustily hanged, there is the end of lusty Browne.
Hold your lusty peace, for here come the Lords.
Please it your honours, place yourselves my lords
Bring forth the prisoner, and keep silence there,
Prepare the Indictment that it may be read.
To the bar George Browne, and hold up thy hand.
Thou art here indicted by the name of George Browne, late
of London Gentleman, for that thou upon the xxv day of
March in the xv year of the reign of her sacred
whom God long preserve, between the hours of vii. and
viii. of the clock in the forenoon of the same day, near
unto
Shooters hill, in the county of Kent, lying in wait of
purpose
and pretended malice, having no fear of God before thine
eyes, the persons of George Sanders Gentleman, and Iohn
Bean yeoman, then and there journeying in Gods peace and
the princes, feloniously did assault, and with one sword, price
six shillings, mortally and wilfully, in many places
diddest
wound unto the death against the peace, crown and dignity
of her majesty. How sayst thou to these felonious
murders,
art thou guilty or not guilty?
Guilty.
The Lord have mercy upon thee.
Master Sheriff ye shall not need to return any Jury to
upon him, for he hath pleaded guilty, and stands convict
at
the bar attending his judgment. What canst thou say for
thyself Browne, why sentence of death should not be pronounced
against thee?
Nothing my Lord, but only do
beseech,
Those noble men assistants on that bench,
And you my Lord who are to justice sworn,
As you will answer at Gods judgment seat,
To have a care to save the innocent,
And (as myself) to let the guilty die,
That is Druries wife, and her man trusty Roger:
But if Anne Sanders die, I do protest
As a man dead in law, that she shall have
The greatest wrong that ever had
guiltless soul.
She shall have justice, and with favour, Browne
Assure yourself (Browne) she shall have no wrong
I humbly thank your Lordships.
Hark ye Browne,
What countryman are ye born?
Of Ireland, and in Dublin.
Have you not a brother called Anthony Browne?
Yes my Lord, whom (as I hear)
Your Lordship keeps close prisoner now in Newgate.
Well, two bad brothers, God forgive ye both.
Amen my Lord, and you, and all the world.
Attend your sentence.
Presently my Lord:
But I have one petition first to make
Unto those Noble men, which on my knees
I do beseech them may not be denied.
What is it George Browne?
I know the Law
Condemns a murtherer to be hanged in chains,
O good my Lords, as you are Noble men
Let me be buried so soon as I am dead.
Thou shalt, thou shalt, let not that trouble thee,
But hear thy judgment.
Browne, thou art here by Law condemned to die
Which by thine own confession thou deservest.
All men must die, although by divers means,
The manner how is of least moment, but
The matter why, condemns or justifies:
But be of comfort, though the world condemn,
Yea, though thy conscience sting thee for thy fact,
Yet God is greater than thy conscience,
And he can save whom all the world condemns,
If true repentance turn thee to his grace.
Thy time is short, therefore spend this thy time
In prayer and contemplation of thy end,
Labour to die better than thou hast lived,
God grant thou mayst. Attend thy judgment now:
Thou must go from hence to the place from whence thou camest
From thence to the appointed place of execution,
And there be hanged until thou be dead,
And thy body after at the princes pleasure:
And so the Lord have mercy upon thee Browne.
Master Sheriff, see, execution, and now take him hence,
And bring those other prisoners that you have.
My Lords forget not my petitions,
Save poor Anne Sanders for she is innocent:
And good my Lords let me not hang in Chains.

stage.l: Browne is led out, and Anne Sanders, and Drurie brought in.

sp.l: Farewell, let none of these things trouble thee.
See how he labours to acquit Anne Sanders.
What hath his brother that is in Newgate done?
Notorious felonies in Yorkeshire my Lord,
Here come the prisoners: bring them to the bar:
Read their indictment: master Sheriff prepare
Your Jury ready: command silence there.

stage.l: Anne Sanders hath a white Rose in her bosom.

sp.l: Anne Sanders, and Anne Drurie,
To the bar and hold up your hands.
You are here jointly and severally indicted in form
following,
viz. that you Anne Sanders, and Anne Drurie, late of London
Spinsters, and thou Roger Clement, late of the same yeoman,
And every of you jointly and severally, before and after the
xxv. day of March last past, in the xv. year of the reign
of
her sacred Majesty, whom God long preserve, having not
the fear of God before your eyes, did maliciously conspire and
conclude with one George Brown Gent. the death of George
Sanders, late husband to you Anne Sanders, and did entice,
animate
and procure the said George Browne to murder the
said master Sanders: And also after the said heinous murther
committed, did with money and other means, aid relieve, and
abet the said Browne, knowing him to have done the deed,
whereby you are all accessories both before and after the fact
contrary to the peace, crown, and dignity of our
Lady the Queen: how say ye severally, Are ye guilty, or not
guilty, as necessaries both before and after to this
and murther?
Not guilty.
Not guilty.
How will ye be tried?
By God and by the Country.
Bring forth trusty Roger there,
Roger what sayst thou to this letter?
Who gave it thee to carry unto Browne?
My mistress gave it me,
And she did write it on our Ladies Eve.
Did mistress Sanders know thereof or no?
She read it twice before the same was sealed
Did I thou wicked man?
This man is hired to betray my life.
Fie mistress Sanders, you do not well,
To use such speeches, when ye see the case,
Is too too manifest. But I pray ye,
Why do you wear that white rose in your bosom?
In token of my spotless innocence,
As free from guilt as is this flower from stain.
I fear it will not fall out so.
Roger what money carried you to Browne,
After the deed to get him gone withal?
Twenty-six pounds, which coin was borrowed
Part of my mistress plate, and some of mistress Sanders.
How say ye to that mistress Sanders?
Indeed I grant I miss some of my plate,
And now am glad I know the thief that stole it.
O God forgive ye, you did give it me.
And God forgive me, I did love you all,
Too well, which now I dearly answer for.
Anne Drurie, what say you was not the plate,
Part of it yours, and the rest mistress Sanders,
According as your man hath here confessed,
With which she borrowed twenty pound for Browne?
My Lord it was.
And you and she together,
Were privy of the letter which was sent.
Was it so or no? why do you not speak?
It was my Lord, and mistress Sanders knew,
That Roger came the morning ere he went,
And had a token from her to George Browne,
A handkercher which after was sent back,
Imbrued in Sanders blood.
Who brought that handkercher?
That did my man.
To whom did you deliver it sirrah?
To mistress Sanders at her house my Lord.
O God (my Lords) he openly belies me.
I kept my child-bed chamber at that time,
Where it was not meet that he or any man
Should have access.
Go to, clog not your soul,
With new additions of more heinous sin.
It is thought beside conspiring of his death,
You wronged your husband with unchaste behaviour,
For which the justice of the righteous God,
Meaning to strike you, yet reserves a place,
Of gracious mercy, if you can repent,
And therefore bring your wickedness to light,
That suffering for it in this world, you might,
Upon your hearty sorrow be set free,
And fear no further judgment in the next,
But if you spurn at his affliction,
And bear his chastisement with grudging minds,
Your precious soul as well as here your bodies,
Are left in hazard of eternal death,
Be sorry therefore, it is no petty sin,
But murder most unnatural of all,
Wherewith your hands are tainted, and in which,
Before and after the accursed fact,
You stand as accessory: to be brief,
You shall be carried back unto the place,
From whence you came, and so from thence at last,
Unto the place of execution, where
You shall all three be hanged till you be dead,
And so the Lord have mercy on your souls.
Ah good my Lords be good unto Anne Sanders,
Or else you cast away an innocent.
It should not seem so by the rose you wear,
His colour now is of another hue.
So you will have it: but my soul is still,
As free from murther as it was at first.
I think no less, Jailer, away with them.
Well well Anne Drury I may curse the time,
That ever I saw thee, thou broughtst
me to this.
I will not curse, but God forgive ye both,
For had I never known nor you nor her,
I had not come unto this shameful death.

stage.l: Enter master Browne to execution with the Sheriff

sp.l: Why do you stay me, in the way of death,
The peoples eyes have fed them with my sight,
The little babies in the mothers arms,
Have wept for those poor babies seeing me,
That I by my murther have left fatherless,
And shrieked and started when I came along,
And sadly sighed, as when their nurses use
To fright them with some monster when they cry.
You have a brother Browne, that for a murther
Is lately here committed unto Newgate,
And hath obtained he may speak with you.
Have I a brother, that hath done the like?
Is there another Browne hath killed a Sanders?
It is my other self hath done the deed,
I am a thousand, every murtherer is my own self,
I am at one time in a thousand places,
And I have slain a thousand Sanderses,
In every shire, each city, and each town,
George Sanders still is murthered by George Browne.
Brother.
Dost thou mean me?
Is there a man will call me brother?
Yes I will call thee so, and may do it,
That have a hand as deep in blood as thou.
Brother I know thee well, of whence was thine?
Of Yorke he was.
Sanders of London mine.
Then see I well Englands two greatest towns.
Both filled with murders done by both the Brownes.
Then may I rightly challenge thee a brother.
Thou slewest one in the one, I one in the other.
When didst thou thine?
A month or five weeks past.
Hardly to say then which was done the last,
Where shalt thou suffer?
Where I did the fact,
And I here brother where I laid my act:
Then I see well that be it near or further,
That heaven will still take due revenge on murther.
Brother farewell, I see we both must die,
At London you this week, next at Yorke, I.
Two luckless brothers sent both at one hour,
The one from Newgate, the other from the Tower.
Browne: yet at last to satisfy the world,
And for a true and certain testimony,
Of thy repentance for this deed committed,
Now at the hour of death, as thou dost hope
To have thy sins forgiven at Gods hands,
Freely confess what yet unto this hour,
Against thy conscience (browne) thou hast concealed,
Anne Sanders knowledge of her husbands death.
Have I not made a covenant with hell,
That for the love that I ever bare to her,
I will sell her life by my confession,
And shall I now confess it? I am a villain,
I will never do it: Shall it be said Browne proved
A recreant: (and yet I have a soul.)
Well, God the rest reveal:
I will confess my sins, but this conceal.
Upon my death she is guiltless of the fact.
Well, much ado I had to bring it out,
My conscience scarce would let me utter it,
I am glad it is past.
But Browne, it is confessed by Druries wife,
That she is guilty: which doth fully prove
Thou hast no true contrition, but concealest
Her wickedness, the bawd unto her sin.
Let her confess what she thinks good;
Trouble me no more good master Sheriff.
Browne, thy soul knows.
Yea, yea, it does; pray you be quiet sir:
Vile world how like a monster come I soiled from thee?
How have I wallowed in thy loathsome filth,
Drunk and besmeared with all thy bestial sin
I never spake of God, unless when I
Have blasphemed his name with monstrous oaths:
I never read the scriptures in my life,
But did esteem them worse than vanity:
I never came in Church where God was taught,
Nor ever to the comfort of my soul
Took benefit of Sacrament or Baptism:
The Sabbath days I spent in common stews,
Unthrifty gaming, and vile perjuries:
I held no man once worthy to be spoke of
That went not in some strange disguised attire,
Or had not fetched some vile monstrous fashion,
To bring in odious detestable pride:
I hated any man that did not do
Some damned or some hated filthy deed,
That had been death for virtuous men to hear,
Of all the worst that live, I was the worst,
Of all the cursed, I the most accursed,
All careless men be warned by my end,
And by my fall your wicked lives amend.
It is the Council's pleasure master Sheriff,
The body be conveyed to Shooters hill,
And there hung up in Chains.
It shall be done.

stage.l: Enter master Iames with the Minister.

sp.l: Why, then you are persuaded certainly,
That mistress Sanders is mere innocent?
That am I sir, even in my
very soul,
Compare but all the likelihoods thereof,
First her most firm denial of the fact,
Next mistress Druries flat confession,
That only she and Roger did
The death of master Sanders: then yourself
Cannot but be of mine opinion.
Then all you labour for,
Is that I should procure her pardon.
To save an innocent,
Is the most Christian work that man can do
Beside, if you perform it sir, sound recompense,
Shall quit your pains so well employed herein.
Now let me tell ye, that I am ashamed,
A man of your profession should appear
So far from grace, and touch of conscience,
As making no respect of his own soul,
He should with such audaciousness presume
To baffle Justice, and abuse the seat,
With your fond over-weaning and sly fetch.
Think you the world discerneth not your drift?
Do not I know, that if you could prevail,
By this far fetched insinuation,
And mistress Sanders pardon thus obtained,
That your intent is then to marry her?
And thus you have abused her poor soul,
In trusting to so weak and vain a hope.
Well sir, since you have so forgot yourself,
And (shameless) blush not at so bold offence:
Upon their day of execution,
And at the selfsame place, upon a pillory,
There shall you stand, that all the world may see,
A just desert for such impiety.
Good sir hear me.
I will not hear thee, come and get thee hence,
For such a fault, too mean a recompense.
Tom Peart my old companion? well met.
Good morrow Wil Crow, good morrow, how dost?
I have not seen thee a great while.
Well I thank God, how dost thou? where hast thou
been this morning so early?
Faith I have been up ever since three o'clock.
About what man?
Why to make work for the hangman: I and another
have been setting up a gallows.
O for mistress Drewry, must she die today?
Nay I know not that, but when she does, I am
sure there is a gallows big enough to hold them both.
Both whom? her man and her.
Her man and her, and mistress Sanders too, it is a
swinger i'faith. But come I will give thee a pot this
morning,
for I promise thee I am passing dry after my work.
Content, Tom, and I have another for thee, and
afterwards I will go to see the execution.
Do as thou wilt for that.
But dost thou think it will be today?
I cannot tell, Smithfield is full of people, and
the Sheriffs man that set us awork told us it
would be
today. But come shall we have this Beer?
With a good will, lead the way.

stage.l: Enter Anne Sanders and her keeper

sp.l: Called you mistress Sanders?
Keeper I did:
I prithee fetch up mistress Drurie to me,
I have a great desire to talk with her.
She shall be brought unto you presently.
O God, as I was standing at a grate,
That looks into the street, I heard men talk,
The execution should be done today,
And what a pair of Gallows were set up,
Both strong and big enough to hold us all:
Which words have struck such terror to my soul,
As I cannot be quiet till I know
Whether Nan Drurie be resolved still
To clear me of the murder as she promised,
And here she comes: I prithee gentle Keeper,
Give us a little leave we may confer
Of things that nearly do concern our souls.
With all my heart, take time and scope enough.
Now mistress Sanders, what is your will with me?
O mistress Drury, now the hour is come
To put your love unto the touch, to try
If it be currant, or but counterfeit.
This day it is appointed we must die,
How say you then, are you still purposed
To take the murder upon yourself?
Or will you now recant your former words?
Anne Sanders, Anne, it is time to turn the leaf,
And leave dissembling, being so near my death,
The like I would advise yourself to do.
We have been both notorious vile transgressors,
And this is not the way to get remission,
By joining sin to sin, nor both to agree
With godly christians, but with reprobates,
And such as have no taste of any grace,
And therefore (for my part) I will clear my conscience,
And make the truth apparent to the world.
Will you prove then inconstant to your friend?
Should I, to purchase safety for another,
Or lengthen out another's temporal life,
Hazard mine own soul everlastingly,
And loose the endless joys of heaven,
Prepared for such as will confess their sins?
No mistress Sanders, yet there is a time of grace,
And yet we may obtain forgiveness,
If we will seek it at our Saviours hands.
But if we wilfully shut up our hearts
Against the holy spirit that knocks for entrance
It is not this worlds punishment shall serve,
Nor death of body, but our souls shall live
In endless torments of unquenched fire.
Your words amaze me, and although I will hold
I never had intention to confess
My heinous sin, that so I might escape
The worlds reproach, yet God I give him thanks
Even at this instant I am strangely changed,
And will no longer drive repentance off,
Nor cloak my guiltiness before the world:
And in good time see where the Doctor comes,
By whom I have been seriously instructed.
Good morrow mistress Sanders, and souls health
Unto you both: prepare yourselves for death,
The hour is now at hand, and mistress Sanders,
At length acknowledge and confess your fault,
That God may be propitious to your soul.
Right reverend sir, not to delude the world,
Nor longer to abuse your patience;
Here I confess I am a grievous sinner,
And have provoked the heavy wrath of God,
Not only by consenting to the
death
Of my late husband, but by wicked lust,
And wilful sin, denying of the fault:
But now I do repent and hate myself,
Thinking the punishment prepared for me,
Not half severe enough for my deserts.
Done like a christian and the child of grace,
Pleasing to God, to angels, and to men,
And doubt not but your soul shall find a place
In Abrahams bosom, though our body perish.
And mistress Drewry, shrink not from your faith,
But valiantly prepare to drink this cup
Of sour affliction, it will raise up to you
A crown of glory in another world.
Good M. Doctor, I am bound to you,
My soul was ignorant, blind, and almost choked
With this worlds vanities, but by your counsel,
I am as well resolved to go to death,
As if I were invited to a banquet:
Nay such assurance have I in the blood
Of him that died for me, as neither fire,
Sword nor torment could retain me from him.
Spoke like a champion of the holy Cross.
Now mistress Sanders, let me tell to you:
Your children hearing this day was the last
They should behold their mother on the earth,
Are come to have your blessing ere you die,
And take their sorrowful farewell of you:
A sorrowful farewell it will be indeed
To them (poor wretches) whom I have deprived,
Of both the natural succours of their youth:
But call them in, and gentle Keeper, bring me
Those books that lie within my chamber window.
O master Doctor, were my breast transparent,
That what is figured there, might be perceived,
How should you see the very image of poor
And tottered ruins, and a slain conscience:
Here here they come be blind mine eyes with tears,
And soul and body now asunder part.
O mother, mother.
O my dear children!
I am unworthy of the name of Mother.
Turn not your face from us, but ere you die,
Give us your blessing.
Kneel not unto me,
It is I that have deserved to kneel to you.
My trespass hath bereft you of a father,
A loving father, and kind careful father,
And by that self-same action, that foul deed
Your mother likewise is to go from you,
Leaving you (poor souls) by her offence,
A corasie and a scandal to the world.
But could my husband and your father hear me,
Thus humbly at his feet would I fall down,
And plentiful in tears bewail my fault.
Mercy I ask of God, of him, and you,
And of his kindred which I have abused,
And of my friends and kindred wheresoever,
Of whom I am ashamed and abashed,
And of all men and women in the world,
Whom by my foul example I have grieved,
Though I deserve no pity at their hands,
Yet I beseech them all to pardon me,
And God I thank that hath found out my sin,
And brought me to affliction in this world,
Thereby to save me in the world to come.
O children learn, learn by your mothers fall
To follow virtue, and beware of sin,
Whose baits are sweet and pleasing to the eye,
But being tainted, more infect than poison,
And are far bitterer than gall itself,
and lived in, days where you have wealth at will,
As once I had, and are well matched beside:
Content yourselves, and surfeit not on pride.

stage.l: Enter Sheriff bringing in Trusty Roger with

sp.l: What M. Doctor, have you made an end?
The morning is far spent, it is time to go.
Even when you will, M. Sheriff, we are ready.
Behold (my children,) I will not bequeath,
Or gold or silver to you, you are left
Sufficiently provided in that point,
But here I give to each of you a book
Of holy meditations, Bradfords works,
That virtuous chosen servant of the Lord,
Therein you shall be richer than with gold,
Safer than in fair buildings: happier
Than all the pleasures of this world can make you.
Sleep not without them when you go to bed,
And rise amornings with them in your hands.
So God send down his blessing on you all:
Farewell, farewell, farewell, farewell, farewell.

stage.l: She kisses them one after another.

sp.l: Nay stay not sweethearts, and we must part,
That way go you, this way my heavy heart.
Here are the lances that have sluiced forth sin,
And ripped the venomed ulcer of foul lust,
Which being by due vengeance qualified,
Here Tragedy of force must needs conclude.
Perhaps it may seem strange unto you all,
That one hath not revenged another's death,
After the observation of such course:
The reason is, that now of truth I sing,
And should I add, or else diminish aught,
Many of these spectators then could say,
I have committed error in my play.
Bear with this true and home born Tragedy,
Yielding to slender argument and scope,
To build a matter of importance on,
And in such form as happily you expected.
What now hath failed, tomorrow you shall see,
Performed by History or Comedy.
